There is something implicit in the plot that I think is the true intent behind the plot of the film.

We know for sure that there is pedo stuff going on with the cult because the little girl at the costume store knows what costume he needs. She's been there before. Her father is involved and had the costumes needed to get there.

Now what is the common theory as to why these people exist in real life? Why was Jeffrey Epstein a billionaire? Why was he killed? Because pedo sex is how the ultimate powers of our world hold blackmail over the entire planet. The people at this party are not just having fun; they are engaging in both spiritual dark magic but also political power plays. Some people are having sex, some are not. Some women are being newly initiated, some have been there for a long time. People are trading sex and power here.

When Bill is discovered at the party, and the man in the red robe finds him out, what does he ask him to do? He asks him to remove his robe. What would be the point of that? If they were gonna kill him, they'd just take him in the basement and kill him quietly. No; they were gonna have him fuck an underage girl. They were going to use it to keep him quiet and initiate him into the cult. There are numerous signs that he was being led there that night and that he didn't come across it by accident; too many things from Ziegler having the party with all the occult symbolism, testing his trust with the nude overdosed hooker, the two chicks at the party trying to seduce him, him having a contact who is specifically involved in the cults for the costumes, him being told about the party by his friend (you think Ziegler wouldn't have known that he and Bill were college buddies).

Bill was meant to be there. Bill was supposed to fuck an underage girl. That was what Kubrick was revealing with this movie. I can't find any way to ignore this. All of the mysteries of this films center around this point. That moment where Bill was saved.

posts.com:
THE RED CLOAK

It is known Kubrick read every source he could on Napoleon.

The following story has served as "influence" on the Red Cloak. Of course, the color red has been a symbol of power in general, and the Red Cloak sits in front of the two-headed eagle with a sceptre in his hand.

It has often been said that Napoleon periodically saw a phantom called the Red Man. Here’s a summary of the tale, as reported in February 1815, before Napoleon made his escape from Elba.

The following singular story was circulated almost immediately after the fall of Napoleon and with the credulous obtained ready belief.

>The gentleman from whom this curious communication was received heard it related, with the following particulars, on the 1st of January, at Paris, where he spent the whole of the winter: The 1st of January, 1814, early in the morning, Napoleon shut himself up in his cabinet, bidding Count Molé, then Counsellor of State…to remain in the next room, and to hinder any person whatever from troubling him while he was occupied in his cabinet…. He had not long retired to his study when a tall man, dressed all in red, applied to Molé, pretending that he wanted to speak to the Emperor. He was answered that it was not possible. ‘I must speak to him; go and tell him that it is the Red Man who wants him and he will admit me.’ Awed by the imperious and commanding tone of that strange personage, Molé obeyed reluctantly and trembling, executed his dangerous errand. ‘Let him in,’ said Bonaparte sternly. Prompted by curiosity, Mole listened at the door, and overheard the following curious conversation.

>The Red Man said, ‘This is my third appearance before you. The first time we met was in Egypt, at the battle of the Pyramids. The second, after the battle of Wagram. I then granted you four years more, to terminate the conquest of Europe, or to make a general peace; threatening you, that if you did not perform one of these two things, I would withdraw my protection from you. Now I am come, for the third and last time, to warn you that you have now but three months to complete the execution of your designs, or to comply with the proposals of peace offered you by the Allies; if you do not achieve the one, or accede to the other, all will be over with you – so remember it well.’ Napoleon then expostulated with him to obtain more time, on the plea that it was impossible, in so short a space, to reconquer what he had lost, or to make peace on honourable terms.

>‘Do as you please,’ said the Red Man, ‘but my resolution is not to be shaken by entreaties, nor otherwise, and I go.’ He opened the door. The Emperor followed, entreating him but to no purpose. The Red Man would not stop any longer. He went away, casting on his Imperial Majesty a contemptuous look, and repeating in a stern voice. ‘three months – no longer.’

>Napoleon made no reply; but his fiery eyes darted fury, and he returned sullenly into his cabinet, which he did not leave the whole day. Such were the reports that were spread in Paris three months before the fall of Napoleon Bonaparte, where they caused an unusual sensation, and created a superstitious belief among the people that he had dealings with infernal spirits, and was bound to fulfil their will or perish. …

>Who the Red Man really was has never been known; but that such a person obtained an interview with him, seems to be placed beyond a doubt. Even the French papers, when Bonaparte was deposed, recurred to the fact, and remarked that his mysterious visitant’s prophetic threat had been accomplished.

According to website shannonselin: "In fact, the Red Man was a French ghost who had long been said to haunt the Tuileries Palace. He reportedly appeared before Catherine de Medici, Henri IV, Louis XIV and Louis XVI at critical moments of their lives, typically just before something horrible was about to happen to them, particularly their death. After Napoleon’s demise, the Red Man supposedly showed himself before the assassination of the Duke of Berry, and appeared to Louis XVIII on his deathbed. "

All the Red Men were real. There has been a cabal of puppet masters, operating throughout history, who sometimes like to wear full-red attire, and Kubrick exposed or featured them in Eyes Wide Shut with the Red Cloak.

It's not necessarily a lack of talent. One of the main reasons for the tons and tons of timeless AAAA anime made in the 80s and very early 90s is because there was also a ton of garbage too. The timeless ones had essentially infinite budgets, which is not a thing anymore and hasn't been in decades. The economic bubble in Japan was so huge that companies were commissioning these shows just to show they were so wealthy and their business so successful it meant nothing to them how much it cost to produce even if it was very niche appeal that would never make a profit on its own.

You must not be very self aware if you think it wasn't trashing anime in a meta sense. Satoshi life goes from bad to even worse as he's introduced to things like anime, consumerism, MMOs, CP, etc. But the gateway for him was anime and It's not a coincidence imo. The most important line about this comes from Yamazki: "I don't play video, games I make them!". That's the difference between Sato and Yamazaki and why he's never a neet or depressed. Sato is a passive consumer and Yamazki is an ambitious creator.

>>178317221
>I was nearly tortured to death with lightning to prove to him that I believed in his humanity.
To be fair, it wasn't exactly because he trusted in his father, or anything like that.
The ending of Return of the Jedi, is literally just a reaffirmation of the ending of A New Hope.
Luke lets go, stops relying on trying to be in control, and puts his faith in the Force.
His victory is a result of fate having allowed for her sister to to introduce them to the Ewoks, and for his abilities combined with C-3PO's translations to gain their aid on the surface, and Vader's remaining spark of goodness.
While Luke could feel the goodness inside Vader, Return of the Jedi doesn't end with some sort of scheme by Luke to make his father join him. Ultimately, he just does the thing that allowed him to destroy the Death Star, and which he strayed from in Empire Strikes Back, when he allowed his hatred of Vader for taking both his father, his aunt and uncle and Obi-Wan from him to guide his actions.
Yoda also always talks about how 'he'll know what to do', when he's at peace, i.e. the Force will guide him.
He may have hoped for his father's redemption, but his trust was in the Force, which is why he would have never, ever have tried to take things into his own hands, and even if he did, he would have sought solution in the Force.

How disgustingly pathetic.

>>178322396
Hey, just wanted to give a quick recommendation, in case you're not familiar with the biggest alternative you should try and also upload it to: Archive of Our Own (Or Ao3)

It's less known than FanFiction, but 1) it's way better structured, 2) it's got (in my experience) a much better community and 3) is less arbitrary in what is and isn't allowed (more in how FanFiction has rules like you can't quote song lyrics and niche shit like that rather than in the 4chan sense).

Only downside to Ao3 (which is probably a positive), is that it is slightly gated.
To actually join, you need to go to their site: https://archiveofourown.org/
There, you'll see pic related, and if you click "Get Invited", it will ask you to give your e-mail address, to which in a few days they'll send you a link to actually create your account.
This is mostly (to my understanding) to keep out bot accounts, and people who only want to create an account on a whim to basically shitpost as a Tripfag would, or shit up the comment section of works that are set so only people with accounts can comment. (When you publish a work on AO3, you can choose if anyone can comment or only users with accounts.)

It's pretty damn great, I got an account roughly a year and a half ago after being recommended it also here, though for a completely different fandom.

Used to be, you could hand out invites if you were a user, so I'd love to post one here, but that has been mostly discontinued now so I can't.


In any case, regardless of which site(s) you upload it to, good luck Anon! Hope you find a lot of support! Merry Christmas!

Red Ronnet raised his lantern. “I wished to see where the bear danced with the maiden not-so-fair.” His beard shone in the light as if it were afire. Jaime could smell wine on his breath. “Is it true the wench fought naked?”
“Naked? No.” He wondered how that wrinkle had been added to the story. “The Mummers put her in a pink silk gown and shoved a tourney sword into her hand. The Goat wanted her death to be amuthing. Elsewise . . .”
“. . . the sight of Brienne naked might have made the bear flee in terror.” Connington laughed.
Jaime did not. “You speak as if you know the lady.”
“I was betrothed to her.”
That took him by surprise. Brienne had never mentioned a betrothal. “Her father made a match for her . . .”
“Thrice,” said Connington. “I was the second. My father’s notion. I had heard the wench was ugly, and I told him so, but he said all women were the same once you blew the candle out.”
“Your father.” Jaime eyed Red Ronnet’s surcoat, where two griffins faced each other on a field of red and white. Dancing griffins. “Our late Hand’s . . . brother, was he?”
“Cousin. Lord Jon had no brothers.”
“No.” It all came back to him. Jon Connington had been Prince Rhaegar’s friend. When Merryweather failed so dismally to contain Robert’s Rebellion and Prince Rhaegar could not be found, Aerys had turned to the next best thing, and raised Connington to the Handship. But the Mad King was always chopping off his Hands. He had chopped Lord Jon after the Battle of the Bells, stripping him of honors, lands, and wealth, and packing him off across the sea to die in exile, where he soon drank himself to death. The cousin, though—Red Ronnet’s father—had joined the rebellion and been rewarded with Griffin’s Roost after the Trident. He only got the castle, though; Robert kept the gold, and bestowed the greater part of the Connington lands on more fervent supporters.

Connington edged away from the spreading flames on his hands and knees. “Brienne. If it please my lord.” He spat a glob of blood at Jaime’s foot. “Brienne the Beauty.”

>>178322418
It means that there's not enough space to record information properly and if they recorded linear light the shadows would have fucked up colors (sometimes because of the bad chips in the cameras as well but sequentially because of limited data space), which I went to ep 2 to check and that's the case.
Our monitors are usually 8bpc but the idea is to compromise for them in the encoding (creation of the media file process) not in the production, production has to be highest volume of data possible per every component, then you use human visual system and mathemathical tricks to trickle it down to indistinguishable from original source but much faster and lower file-size result.

For example if their cameras were recording color data at full resolution say 1920p instead of half of it w/e (which is what subsampling did) and also at 10 channels per bit, it wouldn't have 95% of those problems even in linear light because there's simply more data there (again not technically true but because of digital noise/digital "film grain" it kind of works)...

https://www.unravel.com.au/understanding-gamma
read this

>>178323010
Yea and hence in production they worked with very high resolution faces, that's why they even had to smooth them out to match their shitty production-pipe.
Now if they print it on film all I'm telling you is that the CG elements on screen, basically 70% of every frame in the entire film is not actually 4k+ (not even the faces again because they imprint the digitally smoothed ones), it's artificially stretched, it's similar to you using an algorithm now to make a 480p into a 1080p and if the algorithm is good you might say "this shit rocks, I like it".

Women having full custody of kids goes back well before even first wave feminism, it’s based around British Common Law. Now it certainly can be argued that the legal system has a long way to come before we reach full equality, but a few things should be said:

>Radfems themselves reject the idea of custody favoring women because they view it as patriarchal. In other words, men have decided that women are meant to be child rearers based on an antiquated male view of women’s roles. Most rad fems and Mens Rights activists would actually agree with each other if they stoped screaming at each other for a fucking second.
>Most custody cases are settled outside of family court where the dude just chooses to fuck off. Contentious divorces are what get seen most often by judges, and sorry, but if a dude is unfaithful to his wife he’s less like to get full custody. Same goes for women, men just fuck around more often.

I’ve dealt with family court in my line of work. I’ve seen full custody awarded to men, I’ve seen divorce rape perpetrated against women. Things skew to favor women overall, but it’s not to the degree some of these dudes like to think it is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pros
>A surprising mystery that appeared out of nowhere.
>An actually pretty good mystery. The movie plasters the clues and answers everywhere, but also leaves so many red herrings that are both absolutely believable and fit in the narrative naturally. You will most likely guess the wrong way, but it will be completely fair and you have no one but yourself to blame.
>Has actually good twists.
>Fantastic acting all around.
>Great setting.
>Madelyn Cline is insanely hot.

Cons
>As lampshaded by the detective, the mystery is ultimately insanely stupid. You will have more than likely thought of the actual killer and noticed some of the clues, but thrown it away because it is really that dumb, which even though it is fair, sort of takes away some of the fun of the twists.
>I find myself constantly distracted by questioning whether the writing is supposed to be woke or not. Like in Knives Out, there are political opinions being thrown all over the place to indicate "real people," but once again, anyone with a rightwing or conservative opinion is typically undermined or implied to be grossly stupid/evil/incompetent, and the same treatment is not afforded to any left/neutral characters. Once is a mistake, twice is a coincidence, Rian. The third time...
>Especially noticeable is the Elon Musk expy. It could simply be a "stereotypical insane rich guy," and I'm just thinking about it more with the current smear campaign, but with the other politics in play, this negates any attempt at feigned innocence for me.
>There's just something at the core of Knives Out that really just seems to have trouble drawing me into it. The character's don't really wow me, and while the murder mystery is great and obviously done by someone with a love for the genre, just always lacks the je ne sais quoi in the end.
>A fucking scene with COVID masks? Seriously? I want to FORGET this shit, not immortalize it.

Final Grade: C-

>>178306510
But you see anon, the truth is that Harry Potter is one of the dullest franchise in the history of movie franchises. Each episode following the boy wizard and his pals from Hogwarts Academy as they fight assorted villains has been indistinguishable from the others. Aside from the gloomy imagery, the series’ only consistency has been its lack of excitement and ineffective use of special effects, all to make magic unmagical, to make action seem inert.

Perhaps the die was cast when Rowling vetoed the idea of Spielberg directing the series; she made sure the series would never be mistaken for a work of art that meant anything to anybody, just ridiculously profitable cross-promotion for her books. The Harry Potter series might be anti-Christian (or not), but it’s certainly the anti-James Bond series in its refusal of wonder, beauty and excitement. No one wants to face that fact. Now, thankfully, they no longer have to.

>a-at least the books were good though
"No!"
The writing is dreadful; the book was terrible. As I read, I noticed that every time a character went for a walk, the author wrote instead that the character "stretched his legs."

I began marking on the back of an envelope every time that phrase was repeated. I stopped only after I had marked the envelope several dozen times. I was incredulous. Rowling's mind is so governed by cliches and dead metaphors that she has no other style of writing. Later I read a lavish, loving review of Harry Potter by the same Stephen King. He wrote something to the effect of, "If these kids are reading Harry Potter at 11 or 12, then when they get older they will go on to read Stephen King." And he was quite right. He was not being ironic. When you read "Harry Potter" you are, in fact, trained to read Stephen King.

I'm a trans individual who has been on /tv/ for years. I've yet to see any definitive proof that anything which is largely accepted by the trans community is bad for them, and I'm here to address these issues.

Let's get a hot topic out of the way first: gender reassignment surgery is as necessary for individuals experiencing severe gender dysphoria as chemo would be for a cancer patient. Yes, some people still unfortunately kill themselves. But, every single person who undergoes surgery who doesnt is a person whose life is saved. It is not cosmetic, it is life saving.

Secondly, estrogen is not bad for your mind or body in any way as an assigned-at-birth male. There is zero scientific evidence that it is. This is baseless and only serves to scare people away from taking the medicine they need

Third: it can be "too late to change". I am 37 and I only began hrt 5 years ago. Within two years I was visually passing and now my voice sounds indistinguishable from any other woman's.

Finally, that it is bad for children to transition. Most children have no issue with this and think it's cool to know a trans individual. And giving children estrogen does in fact make it easier on them psychologically to go through their lives as a woman. There is zero evidence that any child has experienced adverse effects growing up compared to non-trans children.

I will talk to anyone about any of these things. I'm just sick of seeing baseless bullshit spewed about us on this board. Seeing that stuff early on in my transition made me think about some things I never want to think about again. And anyone who posts pictures of girls who are having trouble passing is participating in psychological abuse.

In writing, there is the ethereal “literature”, which is usually but not always prose with a thesis, and there is “pulp fiction”. Writing which has no thesis, and is relegated to the dime store pulp novels and romance novels and free ebooks on the iTunes story. The main distinction, is the presence of thesis in literature, and absence of thesis in pulp fiction. Which is to say, the film Pulp Fiction has no thesis, if not a thesis of “having no thesis”.

Thus it’s a trick question. The answer is right in the film’s title.
